sn48.48:1.2.pli: “Katinaṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu aññaṃ byākaroti:
sn48.48:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, how many faculties must a mendicant develop and cultivate so that they can declare enlightenment:

sn48.48:1.3.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmī”ti?
sn48.48:1.3.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place”’?”

sn48.48:2.1.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn48.48:2.2.pli: “pañcannaṃ kho, bhikkhave, indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu aññaṃ byākaroti:
sn48.48:2.2.eng: “A mendicant must develop and cultivate five faculties so that they can declare enlightenment.

sn48.48:2.3.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmīti.

sn48.48:2.5.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.48:2.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu aññaṃ byākaroti:
sn48.48:2.6.eng: These are the five faculties that a mendicant must develop and cultivate so that they can declare enlightenment:

sn48.48:2.7.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmī”ti.
sn48.48:2.7.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place”’.”

sn48.49:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
sn48.49:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

sn48.49:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmatā piṇḍolabhāradvājena aññā byākatā hoti:
sn48.49:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer had declared enlightenment:

sn48.49:1.4.pli: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmī”ti.
sn48.49:1.4.eng: “I understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn48.49:1.5.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn48.49:1.5.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then they said,

sn48.49:2.2.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmīti.

sn48.49:2.3.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamānena āyasmatā piṇḍolabhāradvājena aññā byākatā:
sn48.49:2.3.eng: “What reason does Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer see for doing this?”

sn48.49:2.4.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmī”ti?

sn48.49:3.1.pli: “Tiṇṇannaṃ kho, bhikkhave, indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā piṇḍolabhāradvājena bhikkhunā aññā byākatā:
sn48.49:3.1.eng: “It’s because Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer has developed and cultivated three faculties that he declares enlightenment:

sn48.49:3.2.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmīti.
sn48.49:3.2.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’

sn48.49:3.4.eng: The faculties of mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.49:3.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇannaṃ indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā piṇḍolabhāradvājena bhikkhunā aññā byākatā:
sn48.49:3.5.eng: It’s because Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer has developed and cultivated these three faculties that he declares enlightenment.

sn48.49:3.6.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmīti.

sn48.49:3.7.eng: What’s the culmination of these three faculties?

sn48.49:3.10.eng: Of rebirth, old age, and death.

sn48.49:3.11.pli: ‘Jātijarāmaraṇaṃ khayan’ti kho, bhikkhave, sampassamānena piṇḍolabhāradvājena bhikkhunā aññā byākatā:
sn48.49:3.11.eng: It’s because he sees that they culminate in the ending of rebirth, old age, and death that Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer declares enlightenment:

sn48.49:3.12.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmī”ti.
sn48.49:3.12.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’”

sn48.5:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.5:1.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto hoti—
sn48.5:1.4.eng: A mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these five faculties’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn48.5:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto”ti.
sn48.5:1.5.eng: Such a mendicant is called a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.”

sn48.50:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā aṅgesu viharati āpaṇaṃ nāma aṅgānaṃ nigamo.
sn48.50:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅgas, near the Aṅgan town named Āpaṇa.

sn48.50:1.3.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi:
sn48.50:1.3.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta:

sn48.50:1.4.pli: “yo so, sāriputta, ariyasāvako tathāgate ekantagato abhippasanno, na so tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā kaṅkheyya vā vicikiccheyya vā”ti?
sn48.50:1.4.eng: “Sāriputta, would a noble disciple who is sure and devoted to the Realized One have any doubt or uncertainty about the Realized One or his instructions?”

sn48.50:2.1.pli: “Yo so, bhante, ariyasāvako tathāgate ekantagato abhippasanno, na so tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā kaṅkheyya vā vicikiccheyya vā.
sn48.50:2.1.eng: “Sir, a noble disciple who is sure and devoted to the Realized One would have no doubt or uncertainty about the Realized One or his instructions.

sn48.50:2.2.pli: saddhassa hi, bhante, ariyasāvakassa etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ āraddhavīriyo viharissati—akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
sn48.50:2.2.eng: You can expect that a faithful noble disciple will live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

sn48.50:2.3.pli: Yaṃ hissa, bhante, vīriyaṃ tadassa vīriyindriyaṃ.
sn48.50:2.3.eng: For their energy is the faculty of energy.

sn48.50:3.1.pli: Saddhassa hi, bhante, ariyasāvakassa āraddhavīriyassa etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ satimā bhavissati, paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
sn48.50:3.1.eng: You can expect that a faithful and energetic noble disciple will be mindful, with utmost mindfulness and alertness, able to remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

sn48.50:3.2.pli: Yā hissa, bhante, sati tadassa satindriyaṃ.
sn48.50:3.2.eng: For their mindfulness is the faculty of mindfulness.

sn48.50:4.1.pli: Saddhassa hi, bhante, ariyasāvakassa āraddhavīriyassa upaṭṭhitassatino etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ vossaggārammaṇaṃ karitvā labhissati samādhiṃ, labhissati cittassa ekaggataṃ.
sn48.50:4.1.eng: You can expect that a faithful, energetic, and mindful noble disciple will, relying on letting go, gain immersion, gain unification of mind.

sn48.50:4.2.pli: Yo hissa, bhante, samādhi tadassa samādhindriyaṃ.
sn48.50:4.2.eng: For their samādhi is the faculty of immersion.

sn48.50:5.1.pli: Saddhassa hi, bhante, ariyasāvakassa āraddhavīriyassa upaṭṭhitassatino samāhitacittassa etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ evaṃ pajānissati—
sn48.50:5.1.eng: You can expect that a faithful, energetic, mindful noble disciple with their mind immersed in samādhi will understand this:

sn48.50:5.3.pli: Pubbakoṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn48.50:5.3.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn48.50:5.4.pli: Avijjāya tveva tamokāyassa asesavirāganirodho santametaṃ padaṃ paṇītametaṃ padaṃ, yadidaṃ—
sn48.50:5.4.eng: But when that dark mass of ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, that state is peaceful and sublime.

sn48.50:5.5.pli: sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
sn48.50:5.5.eng: That is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

sn48.50:5.6.pli: Yā hissa, bhante, paññā tadassa paññindriyaṃ.
sn48.50:5.6.eng: For their noble wisdom is the faculty of wisdom.

sn48.50:6.1.pli: Saddho so, bhante, ariyasāvako evaṃ padahitvā padahitvā evaṃ saritvā saritvā evaṃ samādahitvā samādahitvā evaṃ pajānitvā pajānitvā evaṃ abhisaddahati:
sn48.50:6.1.eng: When a noble disciple has tried again and again, recollected again and again, entered immersion again and again, and understood with wisdom again and again, they will be confident of this:

sn48.50:6.2.pli: ‘ime kho te dhammā ye me pubbe sutavā ahesuṃ.
sn48.50:6.2.eng: ‘I have previously heard of these things.

sn48.50:6.3.pli: Tenāhaṃ etarahi kāyena ca phusitvā viharāmi, paññāya ca ativijjha passāmī’ti.
sn48.50:6.3.eng: But now I have direct meditative experience of them, and see them with penetrating wisdom.’

sn48.50:6.4.pli: Yā hissa, bhante, saddhā tadassa saddhindriyan”ti.
sn48.50:6.4.eng: For their faith is the faculty of faith.”

sn48.50:7.2.pli: Yo so, sāriputta, ariyasāvako tathāgate ekantagato abhippasanno, na so tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā kaṅkheyya vā vicikiccheyya vā.
sn48.50:7.2.eng: Sāriputta, a noble disciple who is sure and devoted to the Realized One would have no doubt or uncertainty about the Realized One or his instructions. …”

sn48.50:7.3.pli: Saddhassa hi, sāriputta, ariyasāvakassa etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ āraddhavīriyo viharissati—
sn48.50:7.3.eng: The Buddha then repeated Sāriputta’s answer word for word.

sn48.50:7.4.pli: akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.

sn48.50:7.5.pli: Yaṃ hissa, sāriputta, vīriyaṃ tadassa vīriyindriyaṃ.

sn48.50:8.1.pli: Saddhassa hi, sāriputta, ariyasāvakassa āraddhavīriyassa etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ satimā bhavissati, paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.

sn48.50:8.2.pli: Yā hissa, sāriputta, sati tadassa satindriyaṃ.

sn48.50:9.1.pli: Saddhassa hi, sāriputta, ariyasāvakassa āraddhavīriyassa upaṭṭhitassatino etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ vossaggārammaṇaṃ karitvā labhissati samādhiṃ, labhissati cittassa ekaggataṃ.

sn48.50:9.2.pli: Yo hissa, sāriputta, samādhi tadassa samādhindriyaṃ.

sn48.50:10.1.pli: Saddhassa hi, sāriputta, ariyasāvakassa āraddhavīriyassa upaṭṭhitassatino samāhitacittassa etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ yaṃ evaṃ pajānissati—

sn48.50:10.3.pli: Pubbakoṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.

sn48.50:10.4.pli: Avijjāya tveva tamokāyassa asesavirāganirodho santametaṃ padaṃ paṇītametaṃ padaṃ, yadidaṃ—

sn48.50:10.5.pli: sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.

sn48.50:10.6.pli: Yā hissa, sāriputta, paññā tadassa paññindriyaṃ.

sn48.50:11.1.pli: Saddho so, sāriputta, ariyasāvako evaṃ padahitvā padahitvā evaṃ saritvā saritvā evaṃ samādahitvā samādahitvā evaṃ pajānitvā pajānitvā evaṃ abhisaddahati:

sn48.50:11.2.pli: ‘ime kho te dhammā ye me pubbe sutavā ahesuṃ.

sn48.50:11.3.pli: Tenāhaṃ etarahi kāyena ca phusitvā viharāmi, paññāya ca ativijjha passāmī’ti.

sn48.50:11.4.pli: Yā hissa, sāriputta, saddhā tadassa saddhindriyan”ti.

sn48.51:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati sālāya brāhmaṇagāme.
sn48.51:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans near the brahmin village of Sālā.

sn48.51:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn48.51:1.4.pli: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci tiracchānagatā pāṇā, sīho migarājā tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—thāmena javena sūrena;
sn48.51:1.4.eng: “Mendicants, the lion, king of beasts, is said to be the best of animals in terms of strength, speed, and courage.

sn48.51:1.5.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāya.
sn48.51:1.5.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.

sn48.51:2.1.eng: And what are the qualities that lead to awakening?

sn48.51:2.2.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ, bhikkhave, bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati;

sn48.51:2.3.pli: vīriyindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati;

sn48.51:2.4.pli: satindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati;

sn48.51:2.5.pli: samādhindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati;

sn48.51:2.6.pli: paññindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.
sn48.51:2.6.eng: and wisdom are qualities that lead to awakening, in that they lead to becoming awakened.

sn48.51:2.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci tiracchānagatā pāṇā, sīho migarājā tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—thāmena javena sūrena;
sn48.51:2.7.eng: The lion, king of beasts, is said to be the best of animals in terms of strength, speed, and courage.

sn48.51:2.8.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāyā”ti.
sn48.51:2.8.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.”

sn48.52:0.3.eng: In the Land of the Mallas

sn48.52:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappaṃ nāma mallānaṃ nigamo.
sn48.52:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.

sn48.52:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn48.52:1.4.pli: “yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa ariyañāṇaṃ na uppannaṃ hoti neva tāva catunnaṃ indriyānaṃ saṇṭhiti hoti, neva tāva catunnaṃ indriyānaṃ avaṭṭhiti hoti.
sn48.52:1.4.eng: “Mendicants, as long as noble knowledge hasn’t arisen for a noble disciple the four faculties are not stable and fixed.

sn48.52:1.5.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa ariyañāṇaṃ uppannaṃ hoti, atha catunnaṃ indriyānaṃ saṇṭhiti hoti, atha catunnaṃ indriyānaṃ avaṭṭhiti hoti.
sn48.52:1.5.eng: But when noble knowledge has arisen for a noble disciple the four faculties become stable and fixed.

sn48.52:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāvakīvañca kūṭāgārassa kūṭaṃ na ussitaṃ hoti, neva tāva gopānasīnaṃ saṇṭhiti hoti, neva tāva gopānasīnaṃ avaṭṭhiti hoti.
sn48.52:2.1.eng: It’s just like in a bungalow. As long as the roof peak is not lifted into place, the rafters are not stable or fixed.

sn48.52:2.2.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa kūṭaṃ ussitaṃ hoti, atha gopānasīnaṃ saṇṭhiti hoti, atha gopānasīnaṃ avaṭṭhiti hoti.
sn48.52:2.2.eng: But when the roof peak is lifted into place, the rafters become stable and fixed.

sn48.52:2.3.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yāvakīvañca ariyasāvakassa ariyañāṇaṃ na uppannaṃ hoti, neva tāva catunnaṃ indriyānaṃ saṇṭhiti hoti, neva tāva catunnaṃ indriyānaṃ avaṭṭhiti hoti.
sn48.52:2.3.eng: In the same way, as long as noble knowledge hasn’t arisen for a noble disciple the four faculties are not stable and fixed.

sn48.52:2.4.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa ariyañāṇaṃ uppannaṃ hoti, atha catunnaṃ indriyānaṃ …pe… avaṭṭhiti hoti.
sn48.52:2.4.eng: But when noble knowledge has arisen for a noble disciple the four faculties become stable and fixed.

sn48.52:3.2.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, and immersion.

sn48.52:3.3.pli: Paññavato, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa tadanvayā saddhā saṇṭhāti, tadanvayaṃ vīriyaṃ saṇṭhāti, tadanvayā sati saṇṭhāti, tadanvayo samādhi saṇṭhātī”ti.
sn48.52:3.3.eng: When a noble disciple has wisdom, the faith, energy, mindfulness, and immersion that follow along with that become stabilized.”

sn48.53:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
sn48.53:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

sn48.53:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn48.53:1.4.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma sekho bhikkhu sekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘sekhosmī’ti pajāneyya, asekho bhikkhu asekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘asekhosmī’ti pajāneyyā”ti?
sn48.53:1.4.eng: “Mendicants, is there a way that a mendicant who is a trainee, standing at the level of a trainee, can understand that they are a trainee? And that a mendicant who is an adept, standing at the level of an adept, can understand that they are an adept?”

sn48.53:2.1.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn48.53:2.2.pli: “atthi, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma sekho bhikkhu sekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘sekhosmī’ti pajāneyya, asekho bhikkhu asekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘asekhosmī’ti pajāneyya.
sn48.53:2.2.eng: “There is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee, standing at the level of a trainee, can understand that they are a trainee, and that a mendicant who is an adept, standing at the level of an adept, can understand that they are an adept.

sn48.53:3.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma sekho bhikkhu sekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘sekhosmī’ti pajānāti?
sn48.53:3.1.eng: And what is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee?

sn48.53:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti—
sn48.53:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant who is a trainee truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn48.53:3.3.pli: ayampi kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma sekho bhikkhu sekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘sekhosmī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.53:3.3.eng: This is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee.

sn48.53:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
sn48.53:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant who is a trainee reflects:

sn48.53:4.2.pli: ‘atthi nu kho ito bahiddhā añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yo evaṃ bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ tathaṃ dhammaṃ deseti yathā bhagavā’ti?
sn48.53:4.2.eng: ‘Is there any other ascetic or brahmin elsewhere whose teaching is as true, as real, as accurate as that of the Buddha?’

sn48.53:4.4.pli: ‘natthi kho ito bahiddhā añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā yo evaṃ bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ tathaṃ dhammaṃ deseti yathā bhagavā’ti.
sn48.53:4.4.eng: ‘There is no other ascetic or brahmin elsewhere whose teaching is as true, as real, as accurate as that of the Buddha.’

sn48.53:4.5.pli: Ayampi kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma sekho bhikkhu sekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘sekhosmī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.53:4.5.eng: This too is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee.

sn48.53:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu pañcindriyāni pajānāti—
sn48.53:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant who is a trainee understands the five faculties:

sn48.53:5.2.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.53:5.3.pli: Yaṅgatikāni yaṃparamāni yaṃphalāni yaṃpariyosānāni. Na heva kho kāyena phusitvā viharati;
sn48.53:5.3.eng: And although they don’t have direct meditative experience of their destination, apex, fruit, and culmination,

sn48.53:5.4.eng: they do see them with penetrating wisdom.

sn48.53:5.5.pli: Ayampi kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma sekho bhikkhu sekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘sekhosmī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.53:5.5.eng: This too is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee.

sn48.53:6.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma asekho bhikkhu asekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘asekhosmī’ti pajānāti?
sn48.53:6.1.eng: And what is the way that a mendicant who is an adept can understand that they are an adept?

sn48.53:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asekho bhikkhu pañcindriyāni pajānāti—
sn48.53:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant who is an adept understands the five faculties:

sn48.53:6.3.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.53:6.4.pli: Yaṅgatikāni yaṃparamāni yaṃphalāni yaṃpariyosānāni. Kāyena ca phusitvā viharati;
sn48.53:6.4.eng: They have direct meditative experience of their destination, apex, fruit, and culmination,

sn48.53:6.5.eng: and they see them with penetrating wisdom.

sn48.53:6.6.pli: Ayampi kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma asekho bhikkhu asekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘asekhosmī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.53:6.6.eng: This is a way that a mendicant who is an adept can understand that they are an adept.

sn48.53:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, asekho bhikkhu cha indriyāni pajānāti.
sn48.53:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant who is an adept understands the six faculties:

sn48.53:7.2.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn48.53:7.3.pli: imāni kho cha indriyāni sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjhissanti, aññāni ca cha indriyāni na kuhiñci kismiñci uppajjissantī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.53:7.3.eng: They understand: ‘These six faculties will totally and utterly cease without anything left over. And no other six faculties will arise anywhere anyhow.’

sn48.53:7.4.pli: Ayampi kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo yaṃ pariyāyaṃ āgamma asekho bhikkhu asekhabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito ‘asekhosmī’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn48.53:7.4.eng: This too is a way that a mendicant who is an adept can understand that they are an adept.”

sn48.54:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici jaṅgalānaṃ pāṇānaṃ padajātāni sabbāni tāni hatthipade samodhānaṃ gacchanti, hatthipadaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—mahantattena;
sn48.54:1.1.eng: “The footprints of all creatures that walk can fit inside an elephant’s footprint, so an elephant’s footprint is said to be the biggest of them all.

sn48.54:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yāni kānici padāni bodhāya saṃvattanti, paññindriyaṃ padaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāya.
sn48.54:1.2.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the steps that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.

sn48.54:1.3.pli: Katamāni ca, bhikkhave, padāni bodhāya saṃvattanti?
sn48.54:1.3.eng: And what are the steps that lead to awakening?

sn48.54:1.4.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ, bhikkhave, padaṃ, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati;

sn48.54:1.8.eng: and wisdom are steps that lead to awakening, in that they lead to becoming awakened.

sn48.54:1.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici jaṅgalānaṃ pāṇānaṃ padajātāni sabbāni tāni hatthipade samodhānaṃ gacchanti, hatthipadaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—mahantattena;
sn48.54:1.9.eng: The footprints of all creatures that walk can fit inside an elephant’s footprint, so an elephant’s footprint is said to be the biggest of them all.

sn48.54:1.10.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yāni kānici padāni bodhāya saṃvattanti, paññindriyaṃ padaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāyā”ti.
sn48.54:1.10.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the steps that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.”

sn48.55:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci sāragandhā, lohitacandanaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.55:1.1.eng: “Of all kinds of fragrant heartwood, red sandalwood is said to be the best.

sn48.55:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāya.
sn48.55:1.2.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.

sn48.55:1.3.eng: And what are the qualities that lead to awakening?

sn48.55:1.4.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ, bhikkhave, bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.

sn48.55:1.8.pli: paññindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.
sn48.55:1.8.eng: and wisdom are qualities that lead to awakening, in that they lead to becoming awakened.

sn48.55:1.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci sāragandhā, lohitacandanaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.55:1.9.eng: Of all kinds of fragrant heartwood, red sandalwood is said to be the best.

sn48.55:1.10.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāyā”ti.
sn48.55:1.10.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.”

sn48.56:1.1.pli: “Ekadhamme patiṭṭhitassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni honti subhāvitāni.
sn48.56:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant is grounded in one thing the five faculties become developed, well developed.

sn48.56:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cittaṃ rakkhati āsavesu ca sāsavesu ca dhammesu.
sn48.56:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant looks after their mind when it comes to defilements and things that stimulate defilements.

sn48.56:1.6.pli: Tassa cittaṃ rakkhato āsavesu ca sāsavesu ca dhammesu saddhindriyampi bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.
sn48.56:1.6.eng: As they do so the faculties of faith,

sn48.56:1.11.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, ekadhamme patiṭṭhitassa bhikkhuno pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni honti subhāvitānī”ti.
sn48.56:1.11.eng: That’s how when a mendicant is grounded in one thing the five faculties become developed, well developed.”

sn48.57:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn48.57:1.1.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

sn48.57:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn48.57:1.2.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn48.57:1.3.pli: “pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni amatogadhāni honti amataparāyaṇāni amatapariyosānāni.
sn48.57:1.3.eng: “When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they have freedom from death as their objective, destination, and culmination.

sn48.57:1.5.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ amatogadhaṃ hoti amataparāyaṇaṃ amatapariyosānaṃ.

sn48.57:1.9.pli: paññindriyaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ amatogadhaṃ hoti amataparāyaṇaṃ amatapariyosānaṃ.

sn48.57:1.10.pli: Imāni pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni amatogadhāni honti amataparāyaṇāni amatapariyosānānī”ti.
sn48.57:1.10.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they have freedom from death as their objective, destination, and culmination.”

sn48.57:2.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
sn48.57:2.1.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

sn48.57:2.2.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn48.57:2.2.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

sn48.57:2.3.eng: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

sn48.57:2.4.pli: Pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni amatogadhāni honti amataparāyaṇāni amatapariyosānāni.
sn48.57:2.4.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they have freedom from death as their objective, destination, and culmination.

sn48.57:2.6.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ amatogadhaṃ hoti amataparāyaṇaṃ amatapariyosānaṃ …pe… paññindriyaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ amatogadhaṃ hoti amataparāyaṇaṃ amatapariyosānaṃ.
sn48.57:2.6.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.57:2.7.pli: Imāni pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni amatogadhāni honti amataparāyaṇāni amatapariyosānāni.
sn48.57:2.7.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they have freedom from death as their objective, destination, and culmination.

sn48.57:3.1.pli: Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, bhante, kassape sammāsambuddhe brahmacariyaṃ acariṃ.
sn48.57:3.1.eng: Once upon a time, sir, I lived the spiritual life under the fully awakened Buddha Kassapa.

sn48.57:3.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, imesaṃyeva pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā kāmesu kāmacchandaṃ virājetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ brahmalokaṃ upapanno.
sn48.57:3.4.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these same five faculties I lost desire for sensual pleasures. When my body broke up, after death, I was reborn in a good place, in the realm of divinity.

sn48.57:3.7.eng: That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

sn48.57:3.8.pli: Ahametaṃ jānāmi, ahametaṃ passāmi yathā imāni pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni amatogadhāni honti amataparāyaṇāni amatapariyosānānī”ti.
sn48.57:3.8.eng: I know and see how when these five faculties are developed and cultivated they have freedom from death as their objective, destination, and culmination.”
